g.text: during the hardening process. Since the simplified model was only an axisymmetric slice of the whole circumfer-
ence, the inductor was represented as a coil of rectangular cross section (w
5.4 mm apart, distanced 0.5 mm from the bearing surface. The model air space had a radius
250 mm. Homogeneous Dirichlet boundary conditions were defined at all surfaces; these confined the
magnetic field to the simulated geometry by acting as magnetic insulation. This was well suited, since the field
was assumed to be axisymmetric and to not extend past the dimensions of the defined cylinder of air. The mesh
within the rod was generated from hexagons with a set width of e
divided into 15 elements geometrically scaled from e
m at the surface to e
generated procedurally to scale from 1.5 mm at the coil surface to e
15 mm at the model boundary, while
the coils were modelled one element thick with a wall thickness of 1 mm. The load was a sine wave current with
1850 A and a frequency of f
10.5 kHz. This amperage was based on a measurement on the
induction coil, but increased slightly to result in a solution close to the assumed maximum surface temperature of
1050 °C. The heat transfer model used only the mesh of the rod, and applied a convective film boundary condition
K and ambient radiation condition assuming the surface emissivity to be
temperature distribution was set to be a uniform room temperature 25 °C and the rod was heated for t
The resulting distribution shows the temperature envelope, i.e. the maximum reached throughout the pro-
cess, along the path shown in Fig.
. While the surface temperature was dialled in to the assumed 1050 °C, it’s
envelope was found to be too hight for the observed internal transformation depths. Assuming a linear scaling of
the entire distribution, it was fitted to the measured depth of phase transitions and their associated temperatures
minimizing the sum of squared residuals. This resulted in an estimated surface temperature of 985 °C (see Fig.
m depth: pure martensite with some

material does not entirely reach Ac
any more due to local differences in chemistry (segregations). In (
m, the original ferritic areas only partly transformed into the austenitic phase, remaining in their
original structure of the base metal. In (
), the first traces of pearlite are found at 4400
microstructure did not transform into austenite, indicating that the end temperature for Ac
